while infrastructuring. This timely work 
contributes to our understanding of how trust and

distrust are shaped by the information production 
representation and dissemination through social

media and emerging COVID-19 data platforms 
and how trust and distrust shift over time.

Our observations on the coexistence of trust 
and distrust are referred to as bonded trust.

Then recall that this trust regarding the 
COVID-19 data decreaseS over time, but we ask why?

Our interview suggests that participants' 
distrust decreased as data discrepancy

across data platforms reduced. Therefore, we 
are in the stage of trusting and distrusting

data production procedures. As such, his trust 
exists and dominates but is tempered by distrust.

Our observations on the coexistence of trust

of over-generalizing individual cases. Then let's 
turn to P08 who worked at the public health sector

and his daily job is "fixing death records 
because data is critical during COVID and we

were constantly trying to make sure that they 
were recorded properly and data is accurate.

Well, one might argue that it is the nature of 
P08's occupation being a staff working in a public

health sector that influences his response, 
but let's take a look at what he said next.

"Right now because of our famous reimbursement 
program, we are seeing a lot of COVID being

added to death records. I'm totally not unsure 
what's going on to do with national stats, but

i think the numbers are going to be a little bit 
artificially higher because of these programs."

Well, taken together these quotes suggest 
that P08 believed that the COVID-19 data,

in general, was truthful, but had reasons to 
be suspicious in other respects regarding the

data production procedures. As such, his trust 
exists and dominates but is tempered by distrust.

Other than the distrust in social media, 
participants also expressed their distrust

in more fundamental information: the COVID 
data. Our study data suggests 35 percent

of the respondents believed that the COVID-19 
data was intentionally inaccurately reported.

However, this number significantly decreased 
over time, suggesting a decrease in distrust.

And there's no significant change in the 
frequency of getting this information.

Additionally, we find that distrust in information 
about the COVID-19 data was negatively associated

with the frequency in which individuals received 
information about it. These results motivated

Additionally we observed a 
shift in trustee occurred,

meaning that who were what people trusted shifts 
from information on social media to social media

platforms themselves. People's past experiences 
with misinformation on social media has produced

a generalized distrust for these platforms 
in their entirety. Once distrust is ingrained

into the truster or people, it consequently 
makes rebuilding trust more challenging.

Other than the distrust in social media, 
participants also expressed their distrust

Due to COVID-19, the past two years 
have been marked by a sense of confusion

and uncertainty as people navigate 
this new public health crisis.

People receive and share information about 
COVID-19 through multiple channels in the

face of uncertainty during the COVID-19 
crisis, it is important to ask to what

extent do people trust COVID-19 information, 
from which information sources and platforms,

and how does trust develop over time?
To answer this question we conducted

and how does trust develop over time?
To answer this question we conducted

a mixed-methods longitudinal study including an 
eight-wave survey from September to December 2020,

focused on lower-income 
groups in the United States
who have been heavily impacted by the pandemic.

The survey questions focused on 
understanding people's information practices

during COVID-19 and their level of trust towards 
COVID-related information and information sources.

177 respondents completed all waves of 
the survey. After survey data analysis

177 respondents completed all waves of 
the survey. After survey data analysis

between April and July 2021, we continued 
doing an interview study with 21 participants.

One question we asked was if people use social 
media for getting COVID-19 information in the past

week. Our survey data suggests a significant 
decrease in social media use over time.

But why do we see this decline?
Our interview data suggest that a decline in

trust accounted for the largest change in social 
media use for COVID-information consumption.

trust accounted for the largest change in social 
media use for COVID-information consumption.

An inability to change others' misbelief and 
mistrust led to the non-use of social media.

For participants who still use social 
media for COVID-19 information consumption,

many people mentioned they used but not relied on 
it, indicating they neither reached an adequate

level of trust for information from social 
media nor did they use it for making decisions.

Our findings through triangulation 
of the survey and interview data

Our findings through triangulation 
of the survey and interview data

directly contradict other work and articles 
regarding the use and reliance on social media.

We argue that we need to take great care in what 
is inferred from the survey responses. Therefore

it is important to differentiate the use 
of social media from the reliance on it.

Additionally we observed a 
shift in trustee occurred,

with the frequency in which individuals received 
information about it. These results motivated

us to ask in the interview study: in what ways is 
distrust associated with information consumption?

Now let's take a look at the relationship 
between participants' information consumption

and their level of distrust. These dots 
represent survey respondents' average of values

across all waves. The colored dots represent 
interview participants' data. As one example,

let's find where P06 and P08 are located.
P6 is located at the top left corner

indicating that he had received little 
COVID information but had high distrust;

whereas P8 is located at the bottom right 
corner, indicating that he had received a

lot of information about COVID-19 and had low 
distrust. When examining why people like P06 held

lot of information about COVID-19 and had low 
distrust. When examining why people like P06 held

strong distrust, we find the participants' 
distrust arises from skepticism in the validity

of the COVID-19 data production processes. For 
example, P06 was saying: "my friend's dad had

a heart failure and died. They took the PCR test 
and it was negative... But at the end, the death

certificate says it's COVID. Somebody's getting 
paid for putting COVID on the death certificate,

so that contributes to the inflation number. 
While his reasoning process alongside his little

information consumption suggests that he relied 
on the information he received from his personal

network. This information serves as his baseline 
to evaluate the trustworthiness and the validity

of the coordinating data. Well, only relying on 
information from personal networks runs the risk

of over-generalizing individual cases. Then let's 
turn to P08 who worked at the public health sector
